Ask yourself a few simple questions….Our hope is that you answered, “Yes,” to all of the above questions, and that’s what we love about food: It is a common bond we all share, a single thread that when talked about, brings to mind all sorts of stories and experiences that we can share.Farmers’ markets are a centre of commerce and socializing, a venue for combining old with new and a place for new ideas to be explored and celebrated.The Cambridge Farmers’ Market (CFM) is our community food hub. It is where residents gather to talk about food and community happenings. It’s where awareness is built and the beginnings of change takes place.The CFM dates back to the 1830s with the current market building holding its seat on Dickson Street since 1887. The presence of the market in conjunction with other civic structures, the Town Halls, is an English tradition that is as relevant today as it was when the market was built.The CFM building’s continued use as a market is unique in Ontario. While other markets either remain outdoors only or have had their original buildings converted for other uses, the CFM has continued to flourish in its original location in its original building for its original intended use and this should be celebrated.As you explore the market, the sweet and spicy aromas of hot prepared foods and snacks will tempt you, along with an extensive selection of cheeses, chutneys, pies, confections, specialty oils, preserves, and seasonal fruits and vegetables.A wide range of local growers and food producers can supply you with all your needs from savoury appetizers to mouth-watering desserts.Our market wouldn’t exist without those dedicated vendors, some of whom have been a part of our team for over 50 years. They arrive in the snow and in the rain, or in the heat of summer, often setting up as early as 3:30 in the morning and many don’t pack up until more than 12 hours later.We have 26 year-round vendors and 30 seasonal vendors, averaging 56 vendors at the peak of the market season, who supply approximately 35,000 shopper visits each year.You can learn more about our vendors by visiting the vendor directory on our website, cambridgefarmersmarket.ca.The Cambridge Farmers' Market is open Saturdays from 7 am to 1 pm, year-round. It is located at the corner of Ainslie Street and Dickson Street, in the heart of downtown Cambridge, and parking is available nearby.For more information, visit cambridgefarmersmarket.ca

Ho Ho Ho! Santa Claus is coming to town, and he's stopping by the Ken Seiling Waterloo Region Museum for a festive Pancake Breakfast Party that's perfect for children of all ages!Santa himself will be making a special appearance, so bring your holiday wishes and get ready to snap some memorable photos with the jolly old man in red.Our expert chefs will be whipping up a mouth-watering selection of pancakes to satisfy your taste buds. Fluffy and golden, they'll be served hot and fresh, making for the perfect holiday treat.Let your creativity shine as you decorate your pancakes with a variety of delectable toppings. From syrup and chocolate chips to whipped cream and fresh berries, you can customize your pancakes just the way you like them!Enjoy a selection of beverages, including coffee, hot chocolate, and juice, to accompany your scrumptious pancakes.Beyond the pancake breakfast, there will be seasonal crafts, games, and activities for the little ones to enjoy, making it a morning filled with merriment.Ticket Information:Adults: $20 Children (under 12): $15 (membership 10% discount applies)Don't miss this chance to create lasting holiday memories with your family and friends. Get into the festive spirit at the Ken Seiling Waterloo Region Museum's Pancake Breakfast Party with Santa on December 2! Be sure to book your tickets in advance, as this event is sure to be a sell-out. Reserve your spot today for a morning of joy, delicious pancakes, and cherished moments with Santa Claus himself. See you there!

description: This event has been cancelled.Join us for a Kid’s Holiday Craft Day at McDougall Cottage!Our cozy little Cottage will be decked out in festive style as we get into the spirit of the season with a special holiday craft day just for the kids!All who join us will be creating two winter-themed crafts to take home - a Jolly Sock Snowman and a Winter Spirit Gnome...and we know that no Holiday Craft Day would be complete without a treat or two, so we’ll have some warm apple cider and cookies ready and waiting!REGISTRATION: Please pre-register for either the morning or the afternoon session:Best for kids age 5 yrs. and up.  Participants must be accompanied by an adult.We can't wait to share the magic of the season with you - we’ll look forward to seeing you on December 2nd!

The 43rd annual Hespeler Santa Claus Parade.When: Sat Dec 2, 2023 at 12 noonWhere: Queen StreetVisit Santa Claus after the parade at the Hespeler Scout House in Forbes Park.  Santa will be giving out bags of candies and special treats, wonderful photo opportunity!

The weather may be frightful, but our Wintry Crafternoons are nothing but delightful! We will be holding our family friendly Wintry Crafternoons every weekend in December from 12 until 4 pm to celebrate the winter season! Our Crafternoons are included in the price of admission, enjoy a wonderful craft and tour of our historic house in its coziest season!Love snowball fights but hate getting soggy socks? Join us December 2nd or 3rd to create a “Snowman pom pom launcher” that brings the fun of snowball fights indoors!Roll up your sleeves and get ready for messy play on December 9th and 10th when we make “Melted Snowman Slime”!Let it snow, let it snow, let it snow! On December 16th and 17th we will be creating “Hanging Beaded Snowflakes” that are sure to add winter charm to your home.Join us December 23rd to create your very own “Wooden Bead Snowman” that makes a fantastic ornament or use your imagination and create your own custom holiday card to give to someone special in your life!December 27 and 28, roll up your sleeves and get ready for messy play when we make “Melted Snowman Slime”!December 29 and 30 from 12 p.m to 4 p.m. and December 31 from 12 p.m. to 3 p.m. We’re gearing up for the New Year! Join us and make your very own New Years cracker filled with confetti, a treat and a mini toy! This is the best craft to start your New Year off with a “BANG”!We hope to see you at Schneider Haus this holiday season!

Experience the Magic of the Season at Ken Seiling Waterloo Region Museum!Join us for a Family-Friendly December Extravaganza!  Are you ready for an unforgettable, winter wonderland adventure? The Ken Seiling Waterloo Region Museum is proud to present a one-of-a-kind, family-oriented event that will light up your holiday season!Step Back in Time and immerse yourself in the enchanting charm of a historic village adorned with festive decorations. Stroll through our picturesque streets, where yesteryear comes alive, and holiday traditions are beautifully preserved. Gather around the crackling campfires with your loved ones and enjoy the age-old pleasure of toasting marshmallows and crafting scrumptious s'mores. The cozy warmth of the fire will keep you snug and merry. Sip on rich, velvety hot chocolate, the perfect medicine to warm your soul on a chilly December evening. Customize your drink with an array of delectable toppings, creating a sweet masterpiece just for you. Indulge your sweet tooth with an array of candies and treats. Discover candy canes, chocolates, and more that will make your taste buds dance with delight. It's a candy lover's paradise!Bring the entire family for an evening of laughter and joy! Father Christmas himself will make a special appearance, ready to listen to your children's holiday wishes and spread the spirit of Christmas.Enjoy festive tunes and live entertainment, take part in arts and crafts, and embark on a scavenger hunt through the village. There's something for everyone to delight in!Don't miss out on this heartwarming, winter extravaganza that combines the best of the season's traditions and a dash of historic charm! Create magical memories with your family and make this December one to remember.Get your tickets today and let the holiday spirit warm your heart! Join us at the Ken Seiling Waterloo Region Museum for an unforgettable family experience.Ken Seiling Waterloo Region Museum - Where History Meets the Magic of the Season!

This event event is exclusively reserved for children with social, emotional, accessible, and behavioural needs. The sensory-friendly environment offers reduced lighting and a quieter atmosphere to visit with Santa. Families will receive a complimentary digital photograph with Santa to commemorate this magical holiday season.The City of Cambridge, in partnership with Cambridge Centre located at 355 Hespeler Road, has organized four dates for families to visit with Santa. Sensitive Santa will come to town on the following Sundays: November 26, 2023; Sunday, December 3, 2023, December 10, 2023, and Sunday, December 17, 2023, from 9:00 AM to 11:00 AM.Please note that spots are limited, and registration is required on a first-come basis.To register e-mail Yesenia Torres at accessibility@cambridge.ca or call 519-623-1340 Ext. 4292.

Bereaved Families of Ontario – Midwestern Region (BFO) shares practical coping strategies for the holiday season.When you’re grieving, commemorations, no matter what you honour or observe, can be a time of overwhelming emotions, new challenges and unrealistic expectations. description:
LGBTQ2S+ identifying individuals are invited to explore a different creative project each month in a fun and safe space.Join us for this fun, casual program. Together we will explore a new creative project with a guest artist each month. Registration is limited to 2SLGBTQ+ identifying people in Waterloo Region. This month we are exploring collage with Alyssa Pisciotto. No experience is necessary and all materials are provided.About the instructor:Alyssa Pisciotto is a queer artist from LaSalle, Ontario and now resides in Toronto. She graduated from OCAD University in 2016 with a Bachelor of Fine Arts, majoring in Drawing and Painting and minoring in Printmaking. Painting and printmaking are her primary practice. Her current work revolves around themes of colour, line and shape, and how they interact with one another. Alyssa has shown in galleries across Canada and the United States, and has been a part of a year-long special exhibition at TheMuseum in Kitchener, Ontario. Alyssa is currently working with The Art Gallery of Windsor to create and deliver arts programing with their Art With Heart workshop series.This program is offered in partnership with Spectrum, Waterloo Region’s Rainbow Community Space.AGE GROUP: |

eventName: An Evening of Carolling in the McDougall’s Back Garden with Voci Cantanti
description: All are welcome to join us for an enchanting evening of traditional carols with vocal quartet, Voci Cantanti.Put on your coziest winter wear and join us in the McDougall’s back garden where we’ll be lifting our voices in song.  Bring your voice and join in, or just relax and enjoy the sounds of the season!We’ll have warm apple cider and seasonal goodies on hand for all to enjoy.Please let us know if you’ll be joining us by registering in advance. Admission is by donation.This is an outdoor event, so be sure to dress for the weather!Bio: Voci Cantanti came together prior to the pandemic, having been inspired to form after attending a Rescue Junction performance. Now under the direction of Amy Di Nino, Voci Cantanti performs a variety of genres and styles in many different languages, with a focus on connecting with the community through the power of the voice. Voci Cantanti members are; Carolyn Cresswell (soprano), Wilma Miyasaki (alto), Gary Greer (tenor) and Jon Cowie (bass).

December 9, 2023 to March 17, 2024Curated by Alix VozAware that movement is self-constructed, Torres is attentive to the forks in our paths and direction changes that shape our contemporary way of life. The installation creates a space of questioning about a reality in which displacement invokes both the fragility and the adaptability of the human being. At the intersection of art and architecture, or rather a product of their synergy, Dérives manifests as a space of freedom paving the way for limitless possibilities. This project materializes as an immersive and organically designed architectural ensemble, beckoning visitors to explore its depths and take ownership of the space itself.Conscient que le mouvement est aussi une construction de soi, Torres est attentif aux bifurcations et aux changements de direction qui façonnent notre mode de vie contemporain. L’installations créent des espaces d’interrogations sur une réalité dans laquelle le déplacement appelle la fragilité ainsi que la capacité d’adaptation de l’être humain. À l'intersection entre l'art et l'architecture, ou plutôt produit de leur synergie, Dérives se manifeste comme un espace de liberté où tous les échanges sont possibles. Le projet est un ensemble sculptural organique et immersif en quête d’exploration, jouant avec le rapport d’échelle en fonction de l’appropriation qu’en fait le visiteur.Explore DérivesAGE GROUP: |
Cambridge Art Galleries |EVENT TYPE: |

Ask yourself a few simple questions….Our hope is that you answered, “Yes,” to all of the above questions, and that’s what we love about food: It is a common bond we all share, a single thread that when talked about, brings to mind all sorts of stories and experiences that we can share.Farmers’ markets are a centre of commerce and socializing, a venue for combining old with new and a place for new ideas to be explored and celebrated.The Cambridge Farmers’ Market (CFM) is our community food hub. It is where residents gather to talk about food and community happenings. It’s where awareness is built and the beginnings of change takes place.The CFM dates back to the 1830s with the current market building holding its seat on Dickson Street since 1887. The presence of the market in conjunction with other civic structures, the Town Halls, is an English tradition that is as relevant today as it was when the market was built.The CFM building’s continued use as a market is unique in Ontario. While other markets either remain outdoors only or have had their original buildings converted for other uses, the CFM has continued to flourish in its original location in its original building for its original intended use and this should be celebrated.As you explore the market, the sweet and spicy aromas of hot prepared foods and snacks will tempt you, along with an extensive selection of cheeses, chutneys, pies, confections, specialty oils, preserves, and seasonal fruits and vegetables.A wide range of local growers and food producers can supply you with all your needs from savoury appetizers to mouth-watering desserts.Our market wouldn’t exist without those dedicated vendors, some of whom have been a part of our team for over 50 years. They arrive in the snow and in the rain, or in the heat of summer, often setting up as early as 3:30 in the morning and many don’t pack up until more than 12 hours later.We have 26 year-round vendors and 30 seasonal vendors, averaging 56 vendors at the peak of the market season, who supply approximately 35,000 shopper visits each year.You can learn more about our vendors by visiting the vendor directory on our website, cambridgefarmersmarket.ca.The Cambridge Farmers' Market is open Saturdays from 7 am to 1 pm, year-round. It is located at the corner of Ainslie Street and Dickson Street, in the heart of downtown Cambridge, and parking is available nearby.For more information, visit cambridgefarmersmarket.ca

Experience the Magic of the Season at Ken Seiling Waterloo Region Museum!Join us for a Family-Friendly December Extravaganza!  Are you ready for an unforgettable, winter wonderland adventure? The Ken Seiling Waterloo Region Museum is proud to present a one-of-a-kind, family-oriented event that will light up your holiday season!Step Back in Time and immerse yourself in the enchanting charm of a historic village adorned with festive decorations. Stroll through our picturesque streets, where yesteryear comes alive, and holiday traditions are beautifully preserved. Gather around the crackling campfires with your loved ones and enjoy the age-old pleasure of toasting marshmallows and crafting scrumptious s'mores. The cozy warmth of the fire will keep you snug and merry. Sip on rich, velvety hot chocolate, the perfect medicine to warm your soul on a chilly December evening. Customize your drink with an array of delectable toppings, creating a sweet masterpiece just for you. Indulge your sweet tooth with an array of candies and treats. Discover candy canes, chocolates, and more that will make your taste buds dance with delight. It's a candy lover's paradise!Bring the entire family for an evening of laughter and joy! Father Christmas himself will make a special appearance, ready to listen to your children's holiday wishes and spread the spirit of Christmas.Enjoy festive tunes and live entertainment, take part in arts and crafts, and embark on a scavenger hunt through the village. There's something for everyone to delight in!Don't miss out on this heartwarming, winter extravaganza that combines the best of the season's traditions and a dash of historic charm! Create magical memories with your family and make this December one to remember.Get your tickets today and let the holiday spirit warm your heart! Join us at the Ken Seiling Waterloo Region Museum for an unforgettable family experience.Ken Seiling Waterloo Region Museum - Where History Meets the Magic of the Season!

December 9, 2023 to March 17, 2024Curated by Alix VozAware that movement is self-constructed, Torres is attentive to the forks in our paths and direction changes that shape our contemporary way of life. The installation creates a space of questioning about a reality in which displacement invokes both the fragility and the adaptability of the human being. At the intersection of art and architecture, or rather a product of their synergy, Dérives manifests as a space of freedom paving the way for limitless possibilities. This project materializes as an immersive and organically designed architectural ensemble, beckoning visitors to explore its depths and take ownership of the space itself.Conscient que le mouvement est aussi une construction de soi, Torres est attentif aux bifurcations et aux changements de direction qui façonnent notre mode de vie contemporain. L’installations créent des espaces d’interrogations sur une réalité dans laquelle le déplacement appelle la fragilité ainsi que la capacité d’adaptation de l’être humain. À l'intersection entre l'art et l'architecture, ou plutôt produit de leur synergie, Dérives se manifeste comme un espace de liberté où tous les échanges sont possibles. Le projet est un ensemble sculptural organique et immersif en quête d’exploration, jouant avec le rapport d’échelle en fonction de l’appropriation qu’en fait le visiteur.Explore DérivesAGE GROUP: |
Cambridge Art Galleries |EVENT TYPE: |

This event event is exclusively reserved for children with social, emotional, accessible, and behavioural needs. The sensory-friendly environment offers reduced lighting and a quieter atmosphere to visit with Santa. Families will receive a complimentary digital photograph with Santa to commemorate this magical holiday season.The City of Cambridge, in partnership with Cambridge Centre located at 355 Hespeler Road, has organized four dates for families to visit with Santa. Sensitive Santa will come to town on the following Sundays: November 26, 2023; Sunday, December 3, 2023, December 10, 2023, and Sunday, December 17, 2023, from 9:00 AM to 11:00 AM.Please note that spots are limited, and registration is required on a first-come basis.To register e-mail Yesenia Torres at accessibility@cambridge.ca or call 519-623-1340 Ext. 4292.

This award winning Christmas market has grown exponentially since its inception in 2012 and this year will offer almost 60 local artisans, crafters and makers. The Cambridge Christmas Market is a favourite shopping destination for unique gifts, seasonal food and a great shopping atmosphere.Saturday, December 9 2023 from 8a.m. - 4p.m. & Sunday December 10, 2023 from 10a.m.-4p.m.Location: Cambridge City Hall (50 Dickson St., Cambridge, ON, N1R 8S1)Saturday, December 9TBDSunday, December 10TBDDowntown Cambridge has lots of free parking near the event.  Check out the Public Parking in Galt City Centre map for parking options.

eventName: SOLD OUT - Special Christmas Teas by the Grand at McDougall Cottage
description: Find some time for calm this holiday season by joining us at McDougall Cottage for a jolly Christmas Tea.The Cottage will be decked out in festive style for this classic, seasonal tea that includes tasty finger sandwiches, freshly-baked scones with whipped cream and preserves, alongside some special Christmas treats and, as always, a bottomless tea pot.This would make a great gift for a friend or two - what could be better than great company, cheerful conversation and tasty holiday treats in a cozy, 165 year old stone Cottage?Reservations are required and space is limited, so reserve your spot now!Museum Members receive a 10% discount.Please note:

description: The weather may be frightful, but our Wintry Crafternoons are nothing but delightful! We will be holding our family friendly Wintry Crafternoons every weekend in December from 12 until 4 pm to celebrate the winter season! Our Crafternoons are included in the price of admission, enjoy a wonderful craft and tour of our historic house in its coziest season!Love snowball fights but hate getting soggy socks? Join us December 2nd or 3rd to create a “Snowman pom pom launcher” that brings the fun of snowball fights indoors!Roll up your sleeves and get ready for messy play on December 9th and 10th when we make “Melted Snowman Slime”!Let it snow, let it snow, let it snow! On December 16th and 17th we will be creating “Hanging Beaded Snowflakes” that are sure to add winter charm to your home.Join us December 23rd to create your very own “Wooden Bead Snowman” that makes a fantastic ornament or use your imagination and create your own custom holiday card to give to someone special in your life!December 27 and 28, roll up your sleeves and get ready for messy play when we make “Melted Snowman Slime”!December 29 and 30 from 12 p.m to 4 p.m. and December 31 from 12 p.m. to 3 p.m. We’re gearing up for the New Year! Join us and make your very own New Years cracker filled with confetti, a treat and a mini toy! This is the best craft to start your New Year off with a “BANG”!We hope to see you at Schneider Haus this holiday season!

description: Take a walk through the beautiful light displays in Central Park in Preston during the month of December. Make sure to capture that magical photo moment and share on social media using #CbridgeWinterfest.Enjoy the City wide self-guided experience with friends, family or on your own time! Installations are bright and lit every night through the month of December for your leisure. December 9, 2023 to March 17, 2024Curated by Alix VozAware that movement is self-constructed, Torres is attentive to the forks in our paths and direction changes that shape our contemporary way of life. The installation creates a space of questioning about a reality in which displacement invokes both the fragility and the adaptability of the human being. At the intersection of art and architecture, or rather a product of their synergy, Dérives manifests as a space of freedom paving the way for limitless possibilities. This project materializes as an immersive and organically designed architectural ensemble, beckoning visitors to explore its depths and take ownership of the space itself.Conscient que le mouvement est aussi une construction de soi, Torres est attentif aux bifurcations et aux changements de direction qui façonnent notre mode de vie contemporain. L’installations créent des espaces d’interrogations sur une réalité dans laquelle le déplacement appelle la fragilité ainsi que la capacité d’adaptation de l’être humain. À l'intersection entre l'art et l'architecture, ou plutôt produit de leur synergie, Dérives se manifeste comme un espace de liberté où tous les échanges sont possibles. Le projet est un ensemble sculptural organique et immersif en quête d’exploration, jouant avec le rapport d’échelle en fonction de l’appropriation qu’en fait le visiteur.Explore DérivesAGE GROUP: |

Ask yourself a few simple questions….Our hope is that you answered, “Yes,” to all of the above questions, and that’s what we love about food: It is a common bond we all share, a single thread that when talked about, brings to mind all sorts of stories and experiences that we can share.Farmers’ markets are a centre of commerce and socializing, a venue for combining old with new and a place for new ideas to be explored and celebrated.The Cambridge Farmers’ Market (CFM) is our community food hub. It is where residents gather to talk about food and community happenings. It’s where awareness is built and the beginnings of change takes place.The CFM dates back to the 1830s with the current market building holding its seat on Dickson Street since 1887. The presence of the market in conjunction with other civic structures, the Town Halls, is an English tradition that is as relevant today as it was when the market was built.The CFM building’s continued use as a market is unique in Ontario. While other markets either remain outdoors only or have had their original buildings converted for other uses, the CFM has continued to flourish in its original location in its original building for its original intended use and this should be celebrated.As you explore the market, the sweet and spicy aromas of hot prepared foods and snacks will tempt you, along with an extensive selection of cheeses, chutneys, pies, confections, specialty oils, preserves, and seasonal fruits and vegetables.A wide range of local growers and food producers can supply you with all your needs from savoury appetizers to mouth-watering desserts.Our market wouldn’t exist without those dedicated vendors, some of whom have been a part of our team for over 50 years. They arrive in the snow and in the rain, or in the heat of summer, often setting up as early as 3:30 in the morning and many don’t pack up until more than 12 hours later.We have 26 year-round vendors and 30 seasonal vendors, averaging 56 vendors at the peak of the market season, who supply approximately 35,000 shopper visits each year.You can learn more about our vendors by visiting the vendor directory on our website, cambridgefarmersmarket.ca.The Cambridge Farmers' Market is open Saturdays from 7 am to 1 pm, year-round. It is located at the corner of Ainslie Street and Dickson Street, in the heart of downtown Cambridge, and parking is available nearby.For more information, visit cambridgefarmersmarket.ca

eventName: SOLD OUT - Special Christmas Teas by the Grand at McDougall Cottage
description: Find some time for calm this holiday season by joining us at McDougall Cottage for a jolly Christmas Tea.The Cottage will be decked out in festive style for this classic, seasonal tea that includes tasty finger sandwiches, freshly-baked scones with whipped cream and preserves, alongside some special Christmas treats and, as always, a bottomless tea pot.This would make a great gift for a friend or two - what could be better than great company, cheerful conversation and tasty holiday treats in a cozy, 165 year old stone Cottage?Reservations are required and space is limited, so reserve your spot now!Museum Members receive a 10% discount.Please note:

description: The weather may be frightful, but our Wintry Crafternoons are nothing but delightful! We will be holding our family friendly Wintry Crafternoons every weekend in December from 12 until 4 pm to celebrate the winter season! Our Crafternoons are included in the price of admission, enjoy a wonderful craft and tour of our historic house in its coziest season!Love snowball fights but hate getting soggy socks? Join us December 2nd or 3rd to create a “Snowman pom pom launcher” that brings the fun of snowball fights indoors!Roll up your sleeves and get ready for messy play on December 9th and 10th when we make “Melted Snowman Slime”!Let it snow, let it snow, let it snow! On December 16th and 17th we will be creating “Hanging Beaded Snowflakes” that are sure to add winter charm to your home.Join us December 23rd to create your very own “Wooden Bead Snowman” that makes a fantastic ornament or use your imagination and create your own custom holiday card to give to someone special in your life!December 27 and 28, roll up your sleeves and get ready for messy play when we make “Melted Snowman Slime”!December 29 and 30 from 12 p.m to 4 p.m. and December 31 from 12 p.m. to 3 p.m. We’re gearing up for the New Year! Join us and make your very own New Years cracker filled with confetti, a treat and a mini toy! This is the best craft to start your New Year off with a “BANG”!We hope to see you at Schneider Haus this holiday season!

One of the Region’s most sought after holiday events, the FRIENDS of Waterloo Region Museums' annual Christmas extravaganza at Ken Seiling Waterloo Region Museum is back for one night only!Enjoy the sights of a Christmas past as you wander through the village in its finest lantern-lit beauty. Stroll down the paths and experience the unique ambiance of a historic village holiday celebration.  Enjoy sweet treats as you sip hot apple cider while under the twinkling stars. The evenings’ music, food, and good cheer will surely get you and your family in the holiday spirit.  Don’t forget your camera, as we will have a special guest visiting for a great holiday selfie.Ticket holders will also receive an exclusive behind-the-scenes virtual tour showcasing the historic buildings in the village, and the traditions and stories inside.In addition, a Family Gift Basket will be given away for a lucky winner to take home! Each ticket holder’s name will be placed in a draw to win this basket.This Fundraising Event is presented by the FRIENDS of Waterloo Region Museums. All proceeds will support the FRIENDS to enhance the programming and activities that bring history to life at our regional museums.   Much of this event will take place outdoors so seasonal / outdoor clothing is recommended.Admission:  *  Adults $28.00 plus HST,  *  Children $15.00 plus HST. (2 years and younger = FREE).   As this is a fundraising event, there is no membership discount offered. Tickets are non-refundable.**Timed Ticketing:6 pm 250 tickets (mix of adult and children)7 pm 250 tickets (mix of adult and children)

Take the night off and visit Schneider Haus for an evening filled with festive fun! Experience the historic house bathed in cozy candlelight! Enjoy cookies and mocktails by the crackling fire, and live music. While you're here craft an ornament and a seasonal votive holder to take home or gift away! Think you got what it takes to conquer our Trivia Challenge? We’ll be putting your festive knowledge to the test - see if you have what it takes to bring home a prize! Ugly holiday sweaters are highly encouraged! This event is for ages 16 and up.

This event event is exclusively reserved for children with social, emotional, accessible, and behavioural needs. The sensory-friendly environment offers reduced lighting and a quieter atmosphere to visit with Santa. Families will receive a complimentary digital photograph with Santa to commemorate this magical holiday season.The City of Cambridge, in partnership with Cambridge Centre located at 355 Hespeler Road, has organized four dates for families to visit with Santa. Sensitive Santa will come to town on the following Sundays: November 26, 2023; Sunday, December 3, 2023, December 10, 2023, and Sunday, December 17, 2023, from 9:00 AM to 11:00 AM.Please note that spots are limited, and registration is required on a first-come basis.To register e-mail Yesenia Torres at accessibility@cambridge.ca or call 519-623-1340 Ext. 4292.

December 9, 2023 to March 17, 2024Curated by Alix VozAware that movement is self-constructed, Torres is attentive to the forks in our paths and direction changes that shape our contemporary way of life. The installation creates a space of questioning about a reality in which displacement invokes both the fragility and the adaptability of the human being. At the intersection of art and architecture, or rather a product of their synergy, Dérives manifests as a space of freedom paving the way for limitless possibilities. This project materializes as an immersive and organically designed architectural ensemble, beckoning visitors to explore its depths and take ownership of the space itself.Conscient que le mouvement est aussi une construction de soi, Torres est attentif aux bifurcations et aux changements de direction qui façonnent notre mode de vie contemporain. L’installations créent des espaces d’interrogations sur une réalité dans laquelle le déplacement appelle la fragilité ainsi que la capacité d’adaptation de l’être humain. À l'intersection entre l'art et l'architecture, ou plutôt produit de leur synergie, Dérives se manifeste comme un espace de liberté où tous les échanges sont possibles. Le projet est un ensemble sculptural organique et immersif en quête d’exploration, jouant avec le rapport d’échelle en fonction de l’appropriation qu’en fait le visiteur.Explore DérivesAGE GROUP: |

Ask yourself a few simple questions….Our hope is that you answered, “Yes,” to all of the above questions, and that’s what we love about food: It is a common bond we all share, a single thread that when talked about, brings to mind all sorts of stories and experiences that we can share.Farmers’ markets are a centre of commerce and socializing, a venue for combining old with new and a place for new ideas to be explored and celebrated.The Cambridge Farmers’ Market (CFM) is our community food hub. It is where residents gather to talk about food and community happenings. It’s where awareness is built and the beginnings of change takes place.The CFM dates back to the 1830s with the current market building holding its seat on Dickson Street since 1887. The presence of the market in conjunction with other civic structures, the Town Halls, is an English tradition that is as relevant today as it was when the market was built.The CFM building’s continued use as a market is unique in Ontario. While other markets either remain outdoors only or have had their original buildings converted for other uses, the CFM has continued to flourish in its original location in its original building for its original intended use and this should be celebrated.As you explore the market, the sweet and spicy aromas of hot prepared foods and snacks will tempt you, along with an extensive selection of cheeses, chutneys, pies, confections, specialty oils, preserves, and seasonal fruits and vegetables.A wide range of local growers and food producers can supply you with all your needs from savoury appetizers to mouth-watering desserts.Our market wouldn’t exist without those dedicated vendors, some of whom have been a part of our team for over 50 years. They arrive in the snow and in the rain, or in the heat of summer, often setting up as early as 3:30 in the morning and many don’t pack up until more than 12 hours later.We have 26 year-round vendors and 30 seasonal vendors, averaging 56 vendors at the peak of the market season, who supply approximately 35,000 shopper visits each year.You can learn more about our vendors by visiting the vendor directory on our website, cambridgefarmersmarket.ca.The Cambridge Farmers' Market is open Saturdays from 7 am to 1 pm, year-round. It is located at the corner of Ainslie Street and Dickson Street, in the heart of downtown Cambridge, and parking is available nearby.For more information, visit cambridgefarmersmarket.ca

The weather may be frightful, but our Wintry Crafternoons are nothing but delightful! We will be holding our family friendly Wintry Crafternoons every weekend in December from 12 until 4 pm to celebrate the winter season! Our Crafternoons are included in the price of admission, enjoy a wonderful craft and tour of our historic house in its coziest season!Love snowball fights but hate getting soggy socks? Join us December 2nd or 3rd to create a “Snowman pom pom launcher” that brings the fun of snowball fights indoors!Roll up your sleeves and get ready for messy play on December 9th and 10th when we make “Melted Snowman Slime”!Let it snow, let it snow, let it snow! On December 16th and 17th we will be creating “Hanging Beaded Snowflakes” that are sure to add winter charm to your home.Join us December 23rd to create your very own “Wooden Bead Snowman” that makes a fantastic ornament or use your imagination and create your own custom holiday card to give to someone special in your life!December 27 and 28, roll up your sleeves and get ready for messy play when we make “Melted Snowman Slime”!December 29 and 30 from 12 p.m to 4 p.m. and December 31 from 12 p.m. to 3 p.m. We’re gearing up for the New Year! Join us and make your very own New Years cracker filled with confetti, a treat and a mini toy! This is the best craft to start your New Year off with a “BANG”!We hope to see you at Schneider Haus this holiday season!

December 9, 2023 to March 17, 2024Curated by Alix VozAware that movement is self-constructed, Torres is attentive to the forks in our paths and direction changes that shape our contemporary way of life. The installation creates a space of questioning about a reality in which displacement invokes both the fragility and the adaptability of the human being. At the intersection of art and architecture, or rather a product of their synergy, Dérives manifests as a space of freedom paving the way for limitless possibilities. This project materializes as an immersive and organically designed architectural ensemble, beckoning visitors to explore its depths and take ownership of the space itself.Conscient que le mouvement est aussi une construction de soi, Torres est attentif aux bifurcations et aux changements de direction qui façonnent notre mode de vie contemporain. L’installations créent des espaces d’interrogations sur une réalité dans laquelle le déplacement appelle la fragilité ainsi que la capacité d’adaptation de l’être humain. À l'intersection entre l'art et l'architecture, ou plutôt produit de leur synergie, Dérives se manifeste comme un espace de liberté où tous les échanges sont possibles. Le projet est un ensemble sculptural organique et immersif en quête d’exploration, jouant avec le rapport d’échelle en fonction de l’appropriation qu’en fait le visiteur.Explore DérivesAGE GROUP: |

The weather may be frightful, but our Wintry Crafternoons are nothing but delightful! We will be holding our family friendly Wintry Crafternoons every weekend in December from 12 until 4 pm to celebrate the winter season! Our Crafternoons are included in the price of admission, enjoy a wonderful craft and tour of our historic house in its coziest season!Love snowball fights but hate getting soggy socks? Join us December 2nd or 3rd to create a “Snowman pom pom launcher” that brings the fun of snowball fights indoors!Roll up your sleeves and get ready for messy play on December 9th and 10th when we make “Melted Snowman Slime”!Let it snow, let it snow, let it snow! On December 16th and 17th we will be creating “Hanging Beaded Snowflakes” that are sure to add winter charm to your home.Join us December 23rd to create your very own “Wooden Bead Snowman” that makes a fantastic ornament or use your imagination and create your own custom holiday card to give to someone special in your life!December 27 and 28, roll up your sleeves and get ready for messy play when we make “Melted Snowman Slime”!December 29 and 30 from 12 p.m to 4 p.m. and December 31 from 12 p.m. to 3 p.m. We’re gearing up for the New Year! Join us and make your very own New Years cracker filled with confetti, a treat and a mini toy! This is the best craft to start your New Year off with a “BANG”!We hope to see you at Schneider Haus this holiday season!
